title: Uncertainty Propagation for Echocardiography Clinical Metric Estimation via Contour Sampling
author: Thierry Judge (University of Sherbrooke), Olivier Bernard (INSA, Universite Claude Bernard Lyon 1), Woo-Jin Cho Kim (Ultromics Ltd.), Alberto Gomez (King's College London), Arian Beqiri (Ultromics Ltd.), Agisilaos Chartsias (Ultromics Ltd.), Pierre-Marc Jodoin (University of Sherbrooke)
relevance_why: The approach of uncertainty estimation presented here could be adapted to improve audio quality enhancement processes by better quantifying uncertainty in spectral transformations.
background: The research aims to improve the estimation of clinical metrics from echocardiographic images by accurately quantifying and propagating uncertainty from image segmentation to derived metrics.
contribution: This paper introduces the Contour Aleatoric Shape Uncertainty Sampling (CASUS) method to solve uncertainty propagation in clinical echocardiography metrics, achieving high accuracy in uncertainty estimates for clinical applications.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods focused on pixel-wise segmentation uncertainty, lacking explicit connections to downstream clinical metrics.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work models contour-level aleatoric uncertainty, allowing for plausible contour sampling that directly informs metric estimation.

key_innovation: The CASUS framework uniquely predicts uncertainty at the contour level rather than pixel-wise, resulting in more interpretable and clinically relevant uncertainty estimates.
real_world_impact: The findings can enhance clinical decision-making in echocardiography by providing reliable uncertainty estimates, supporting better diagnosis and treatment planning.
limitations: The method may struggle with pixel-wise uncertainty calibration, leading to under-confident estimates in spatial uncertainty.

new_terms.aleatoric uncertainty: **Aleatoric uncertainty** refers to the uncertainty inherent in the data itself, such as noise in measurements, which cannot be reduced by gathering more data.
new_terms.epistemic uncertainty: **Epistemic uncertainty** is related to the model and can be reduced by gathering more data or improving model architecture.
